DataElement.preferredName: Lung Excision Pathology Artery Angioinvasion ArterialInvasion
DataElement.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._A blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart.:A term referring to the presence of tumor emboli or tumor masses within blood vessels and/or lymphatic vessels._Spread of cancer cells into healthy vascular tissue adjacent to the tumor

As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

Property.preferredDefinition: A blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart.:A term referring to the presence of tumor emboli or tumor masses within blood vessels and/or lymphatic vessels.

Concepts.definition: A blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart.
A term referring to the presence of tumor emboli or tumor masses within blood vessels (arteries or veins).
